utterances: You also said that in a very real way, though an unspoken way, he was in a partnership with President Roosevelt.
Well, they both had the same ultimate goal, I think.

And I think Roosevelt, early on, realized that at some point America was going to have to defend itself against Germany, and that it would be wiser to do so in alliance with Britain, rather than doing so after Britain had fallen.
But he faced certain political exigencies during the 1940 campaign that he could not be too overt about that support.
Murrow, on his part, was moving down the same path, realized the same things, but didn't' have the same kind of political pressures on him as Roosevelt did.
Let's get another caller in.
This is Ruby, Ruby calling from Healdsburg, in California.
Yes.
Go...
I was in San Diego when the war hit.
I was on the Enterprise before it went.
Why it wasn't in Hawaii?
It was, all these ships were in San Diego because they were re-commissioned.
That was the end of the '30s, into the '40s, and that's why a lot of people don't realize it didn't go down in Hawaii.
My father was on it, but he got off the ship.
And so he didn't go down with it.
USS...
He lived to be 71.
USS Enterprise, of course...
(unintelligible)
USS Enterprise being one of the few aircraft carriers in the United States Navy.
That's right.
I happened to be on it as a kid and we had dinner there, because it was being re-commissioned.
And all the - that's why a lot of the ships did not go down in Hawaii.
The Pacific Fleet was in San Diego.
Yeah.
My sister was born there.
So my mother was always listening to this stuff.
And then we went to Norfolk, Virginia, so we were in the biggest base there.
My mother worked for the war bond.
And must have listened to a lot of Edward R.
Murrow during those war years.
I did, but I also had a TV in the early '50s, so I did hear him a lot on the television, and saw him.
What did you think of him?
You must have been just a kid at the time.
Well, no. But I mean even when I got married, even in my 20s, when he was still doing stuff from the television, the beginning of television, you know?
Mm hmm.
When news broadcasts were really good.
And I don't think they're all that bad now, but they're not done the same way.
No, they're not.
So I do remember hearing him.
And I remember - see, my mother was born in 1910, so she worked on the war bond.
She happened to have a good education.
And we went back East.
We went from San Diego to Portland, and then we got transferred back East.
Well, Ruby...
We followed him.
Ruby, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate it.
But anyway, it was good and he was good even up until he died.
All right.
Well, I thank you.
Bye bye.
Ah, mode of transport?
And Philip Seib, December 7, 1941, of course, the attack on Pearl Harbor.
And Janet and Ed Murrow had an invitation to dinner that evening at the White House.
Well, that's right.
They had come back a couple of weeks earlier just to take a break from Britain.
They were going to stay in the U.S., see some friends, spend Christmas in the U.S., and then head back to London.
And they were friends with the Roosevelts, and they had set a date with Franklin and Eleanor to have dinner - quiet Sunday dinner at the White House on December 7th.
The president was interested in hearing from Ed about how things were in Britain.
And on the morning of December 7th, Ed Murrow was out playing golf when he heard the word about the attack on Pearl Harbor.
Janet called Eleanor and said well, I guess dinner is off.
And Eleanor Roosevelt said to Janet Murrow, no, we still have to eat, so come on over.
And they went to the White House, and it was a very small dinner.
Eleanor didn't cook.
The only thing she made for dinner ever was scrambled eggs, pudding, and milk, and so that's what the White House official dinner was that night for Eleanor Roosevelt and the Murrows.
the president was in his study working through all this time, and when the Murrow's got ready to leave, Eleanor said to Ed that the president wanted to see him.

So Ed waited in the hallway for awhile, finally got into see the president, was the only journalist to speak with the president that evening, and he went in to see Roosevelt and he said it was no question in his mind that the president had not known that the attack was coming.
And the president also told Murrow that things were much worse in Pearl Harbor than the public had been led to believe.
The president was particularly incensed about the fact that many of the American planes had been destroyed.
They'd never even gotten off the ground.
And upon leaving the White House, Murrow walks past the CBS news colleague, Eric Sevareid, who was there working.
And Sevareid asked him, what did you find out?
Right, and Murrow basically said it's real bad and kept on walking.
And he never revealed that conversation until - the conversation with Roosevelt - until the war was over and Roosevelt was dead.

Roosevelt had never said let's keep this off the record, but Murrow treated that conversation as a conversation with a friend and he also had a sense that, you know, great issues were at stake here, and he didn't just want to be running out and reporting what the president had said.
He wanted to give the president more control over how the news was released to the public about this.
And he was then offered a job in the Roosevelt administration and turned it down.
That's right.
He was offered a job working for the U.S.
war effort, basically in propaganda, and interestingly - this is little known - the British had also offered him the opportunity to come and run BBC News.
And he thought about that for a little bit as well, but then he ultimately decided that his best service to all concerned was to go back to London and continue his work as a reporter.
We're talking with Philip Seib - he's a professor of journalism at Marquette University in Milwaukee - about his new book, which is Broadcasts from the Blitz: How Edward R.
Murrow Helped Lead America Into War.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's get another caller in.
T.C., T.C.
calling from Cincinnati.
T.C.
(Caller): Thank you.
Go ahead.
T.C.: I'd like to say thank you Edward R.
Murrow.
Looking at the course of events and the timeline, who knows what would have happened if Mr. Murrow hadn't made it clearer to American public what was at stake and what was happening.
The previous caller speaking of comparing the current government with Nazism just makes me cringe.
If it hadn't been for people like Murrow, perhaps the evidence would have been running in the United States.
Hitler had plans on the entire world at one time.
Mm hmm.
T.C.: Perhaps lend-lease would have been not as vigorous.
Perhaps the Manhattan Project would've been less successful.
There's any number of things that could have happened that the war could have gone differently.
There were no guarantees from the outset.
And just thank god for Edward R.
Murrow.
T.C., thanks very much for that.
Appreciate it.
But Philip Seib, it does raise the question of, let's say that Murrow had had a slightly different ideological bend.
Let's say he had been persuaded by the Charles Lindbergs of the world that America first was the way to go, that involvement in the war was not the way to go.
He was in a position of extraordinary power.
He used it, and we now know - as you say in your introduction - that he was using it on the side of the angels.
But he had extraordinary power, his to use.
And it could have gone either way.

Well, that's an interesting idea, and certainly, if Murrow had urged on the isolationists as opposed to supporting intervention, I think that would have had significant political effect in the United States, because there was tremendous debate going on.
It would have put even more pressure on Roosevelt, and who knows how Roosevelt would have responded if the isolationist sentiment had been even stronger than it turned out to be.
So, I think that underscores, again, the point of how powerful a journalist can be.
I guess if you come a few years forward, there have been people who said that well, Walter Cronkite, during the Vietnam era particularly, had that kind of influence.
Well, maybe so, but I think it's something that journalists should take to heart, that their words don't just disappear out into the ether.
People do take them seriously, and they can have a profound effect on public opinion, and thus on politics.
